critique: The document establishes a commission to study and control typhus fever, primarily to protect members of the armed forces. It expands executive power by authorizing the Director of the Commission to formulate and effectuate a program for the study and control of typhus fever, employ personnel, and make expenditures. It also centralizes authority in the federal government by directing various federal agencies to assist the Commission. The document prioritizes national security and public health, potentially at the expense of individual liberties. It involves the government in public health matters and promotes social inclusion by protecting the health of all members of the armed forces.
